ygData.subject: Re: [gladiator] A Roleplaying Environment
ygData.msgSnippet: Sounds interesting, I ve played MUD s before but I m not really into the roleplaying part :) However I suggest that you don t use the windows telnet program, I

Sounds interesting, I've played MUD's before but I'm not really into the
roleplaying part :)

However I suggest that you don't use the windows telnet program, I have a
100% failure rate when trying to use it and it seems to be the best way to
freeze your machine and destabalise windows until you reboot :)

I recommend a telnet program called CRT, by Van Dyke Technologies - it has a
free trial version available and is very versatile.  You can find it at
http://www.vandyke.com/products/crt/index.html

There is another program, designed specifically for MUD's, called ZMUD and
it aparently has specific capabilities for use in MUD's rather than being a
generic telnet program.
You can find it http://www.zuggsoft.com/zmud/zmudinfo.htm

- Deathifier (David Storey)

----- Original Message -----
From: <crayner@...>
To: <gladiator@egroups.com>
Sent: Monday, January 22, 2001 6:10 AM
Subject: [gladiator] A Roleplaying Environment


> Hey hey.  There has been a lull of silence on this list, and I
> figured it was due to a real lack of development on the Gladiator
> front.
>
> This isn't directly about Gladiator, but about a game that is similar
> to it.
>
> Are any of you familiar with MUDs?  For those of you who aren't, a
> MUD is basically a game that you connect to with a 100% text
> interface and explore and communicate with other players by typing in
> commands.
>
> Given that description, many of you can see how casual and how stern
> a MUD can be about its 'roleplaying' -- roleplaying is how you play
> your character.  If you play your character like you're talking to
> your pals on ICQ, then you are not roleplaying.  But if you play your
> character like he is really facing off with that enormous dragon in a
> fight to the death, then you are roleplaying.  Roleplaying is
> especially entertaining when there are other players roleplaying with
> you as well, a real drug for the active imagination (which I'm sure
> many of us bear).
>
> I've found a MUD that, while based on a desolate planet called
> Zalanthas, has classes and a history similar to that which your
> Gladiator characters might have.  Some of the beginning classes
> include: warrior, ranger, assassin, burglar, pickpocket, and
> merchant; with subclasses (things that your characters is good at
> second) archer, forester, hunter, physician, house servent, thief,
> weaponscrafter, and even bard.  Reading those probably sparks a few
> ideas about Gladiator characters you've played.
>
> The roleplaying standards here are the strictest of any MUD I've
> seen.  The administrators will intervene if someone around you isn't
> playing their character realistically, and this sort of regulation
> makes playing a hell of a lot of fun.  You really feel like you're on
> a desolate desert planet, striving to acquire resources so you can
> survive another day or two.  Because of the inherent power of the
> magic classes, you have to play one "regular" character fairly well
> before you apply for a 'magicker.'  Every character has a rich
> background and a minimum four-line description which you have to
> submit before you start playing and has to be approved by the
> administrators (which usually happens in under 24 hours).
>
> A rich background, intelligent players, and unique races and classes
> all conform to bring forth the best roleplaying environment I've ever
> played (sounds like an advertisement at this point, doesn't it?).
>
> The homepage for the game is at http://www.armageddon.org/
>
> To play, point your telnet client to www.armageddon.org port 4050
>
> If you're using Windows and are unsure how to do this, your best bet
> is to type in telnet://www.armageddon.org:4050 from the RUN command
> in your Start Menu.  I recommend you visit the homepage first.
>
> If anyone's still interested and would like help, feel free to email
> me ( mailto:crayner@... ) and I'll be glad to.
>
> Take care guys.
>
>  -Chris/Shayd
>
>
> The Gladiator Mailing List
>
>
